name: NPR
text:
A new list from the Small Business Administration shows that the sectors that received the largest share of federal loans under the PPP include restaurants, doctors' offices, car dealerships and law firms.
https://t.co/baNozxZhjM

name: NPR
text:
"I hear a woman in the crowd yell out, 'Don't kill him.' And in that second, I realize that she's talking about me," says Vauhxx Booker, who says a group of white men assaulted him in Indiana on July 4.

The FBI is investigating the attack as a hate crime.
https://t.co/b9AJtYa5Og

name: NPR
text:
Starbucks will require all customers to wear face masks at its U.S. stores starting July 15.
https://t.co/O5pt8KD8TI

name: NPR
text:
Botswana is home to about a third of the elephant population across Africa.

In early May, conservationists started noticing that elephants were mysteriously dying in the country.

No one knows why. (@hereandnow)
https://t.co/8pNRJYJeUP

name: NPR
text:
People are calling for a boycott of Goya Foods after its CEO praised President Trump during a visit to the White House, saying the country was "truly blessed" to have him and calling him "a builder."
https://t.co/bAuJoLwhWo

name: NPR
text:
Defense Secretary Mark Esper told Congress on Thursday that he never received a briefing about alleged Russian practices against U.S. troops in Afghanistan that included the term "bounty."
https://t.co/o3hwiFRsCK

name: NPR
text:
The Trump administration has put visa and asset sanctions on several Chinese officials for what it says is their role in "gross violations of human rights" in Xinjiang, where Uighurs and other minorities have been detained and tortured.
https://t.co/WXiRy7rSmz

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: Watch as polymath musician @jacobcollier makes the impossible possible in his mesmerizing Tiny Desk (home) concert. https://t.co/NFmJkAaf1z

name: NPR
text:
"The goals of the task force were to move the Biden campaign into as progressive a direction as possible, and I think we did that," Bernie Sanders says of the joint effort on policy recommendations for Biden.
https://t.co/cU46l15KEp

name: NPR
text:
A letter to the WHO from more than 200 scientists asks for further investigation into how aerosols may contribute to the transmission of the coronavirus.

Here's what we know about the tiny particles.
https://t.co/Ojd3PwEza9

name: NPR
text:
Principal Pirette McKamey has spent a decade leading an anti-racism committee.

She says being an anti-racist educator means committing to "all of the students sitting in front of me, including Black and Latinx students."
https://t.co/LSMVWSpGJY

name: NPR
text:
A young woman sets out on a mission to free her cousin from a dangerous living situation in a crumbling family mansion in Silvia Moreno-Garcia's new novel, “Mexican Gothic.” 

What ensues is an inspired mash-up of “Jane Eyre” and “Dracula.” 
https://t.co/L5lmY6mlw7

name: NPR
text: Love isn't the main subject in Chloe N. Clark's debut collection of short stories, but it's an important one — these stories dig into the ways we evolve towards each other, form bonds, and feel the earth spin. https://t.co/UqBu2enXbr

name: NPR
text:
Cameo has become one of the fastest-growing tech startups by letting anyone pay for greetings recorded by celebrities.

The talent roster has skyrocketed amid the pandemic, with stars unable to perform and fans trapped at home, unable to socialize.
https://t.co/aq72KRD8AZ

name: NPR
text:
The number of coronavirus cases in Texas is rising at one of the fastest rates in the country.

Rural hospitals, which tend to be smaller and operate on slimmer margins, are scrambling for equipment and staff to combat the surge.
https://t.co/FeebgfzJjg

name: NPR
text:
More big city dwellers are moving to the suburbs and smaller cities. During the pandemic, enough New Yorkers have been exiting that it's shaken up the area's housing market.

One longtime real estate agent says she's never seen anything like it.
https://t.co/u0ODEOxkjO

name: NPR
text: Do yourself a favor. Watch this video of a museum curator describing his favorite object in their collection: the base of a hookah. https://t.co/gJzILoS36u

name: NPR
text:
President Trump has received a second extension to file his annual financial disclosure — which was originally due on May 15.
https://t.co/57CDIA6Yx5

name: NPR
text:
Atlanta Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms is said to be under consideration to be Joe Biden's running mate.

Recently, her handling of protests has put her in the spotlight — as well as speaking out against Georgia's Republican-led response to the pandemic.
https://t.co/cfuQrSnQHq

name: NPR
text:
A Turkish court has paved the way for the government to convert the Hagia Sophia museum in Istanbul back into a working mosque.

The possible change has been condemned internationally.
https://t.co/VVODL37OQD

name: NPR
text: Update: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has ordered the Hagia Sophia to be converted back into a mosque, following the court ruling. https://t.co/Zf3sGAiclA

name: NPR
text:
“Maybe if they hadn't raised me and I didn't have all these heart strings attached to them, I could've just moved on," Hadiyah-Nicole says of her aunt and uncle, who died of cancer. "But I couldn't."

Instead, she broke ground in cancer treatment research.
https://t.co/DhEPH0x4S4

name: NPR
text:
Today @guyraz is checking in – live – with @Eventbrite founder & CEO, @JuliaHartz. 

They'll cover the business of live events, and the resilience needed to thrive (and survive) a pandemic. 

Share what's on your mind these days in the comments below. https://t.co/vRewwqIJ4V

name: NPR
text:
Since the pandemic struck, election officials have made it clear: To avoid a disaster in November, they need more funding.

Senate Republicans are now signaling they may be open to it — but it's unclear how much they're actually willing to approve.
https://t.co/uuU61Bl3N6

name: NPR
text:
A Christian sleepaway camp in Missouri has shut down after it was linked to 82 cases of the coronavirus.

Many of those who tested positive had already left the camp and returned home, with cases in at least 10 states.
https://t.co/ZjYBlVx50z

name: NPR
text:
While more than 20 states now have mask mandates, two of the states worst-hit by the coronavirus— Florida and Arizona — still don't.  
https://t.co/aUb10LOuM7

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRLifeKit: Houseplant hero @hiltoncarter says if you want to be a better plant parent, name your plants! "It's really hard to toss out a plant when it's suffering when it has a name."

So, we want to meet your plants! Send us a pic and tell us their name! 👋🌵💬https://t.co/ecFuloVkzB https://t.co/Jsa0t3j7vB

name: NPR
text:
Authorities are preparing a death chamber in Indiana for the first federal executions in 17 years, starting on Monday.

Death row inmates, spiritual advisers and even some victims' relatives are suing to try to stop or delay the process amid the pandemic.
https://t.co/amygFUQCHX

name: NPR
text:
At 77, Jean-Jacques Muyembe is thinking about his legacy. He was the first doctor to collect an Ebola sample — but his work is often diminished to footnotes in the history books.

That's begun to change. #NPRShortWave 
https://t.co/oQrpP9I6u7

name: NPR
text:
In June, NPR reported that the Education Department was making it harder for colleges to reconsider — and potentially increase — financial aid for students who've lost jobs or family income in the economic crisis.

Now, the department is reversing course. https://t.co/BA1Gwn3yT3

name: NPR
text:
When Chief Justice John Roberts ruled against Trump's move to end DACA, his decision left room for an administration do-over. 

His opinion spelled out every administrative hoop that the administration would have to jump through to get rid of the program.
https://t.co/pwZPqn2SKm

name: NPR
text: A little over two weeks after making a splash over its guidance that education leaders "should start with a goal of having students physically present in school," the American Academy of Pediatrics is changing tone.   https://t.co/7JAS86esW2

name: NPR
text:
As Major League Baseball prepares to start its season, a total of 71 players and 12 staff members have tested positive for the coronavirus.

"I'm actually kind of pleased it's as low as that,”  the league’s medical director said. https://t.co/NJtsL1gBAB
